column3: Units of measurement are developed in the Americas as well as the major Bronze Age civilizations: Egypt, Mesopotamia, Elam and the Indus Valley.[1][2]
The first deciphered numeral system is that of the Egyptian numerals, a sign-value system (as opposed to a place-value system).[3]
The oldest extant record of a unit of length, the cubit-rod ruler, is from Nippur.

The oldest attested evidence for the existence of units of weight, and weighing scales date to the Fourth Dynasty of Egypt, with Deben (unit) balance weights, excavated from the reign of Sneferu, though earlier usage has been proposed.[4]
The concept of area is first recognized in Babylonian clay tablets,[5] and 3-dimensional volume is discussed in an Egyptian papyrus. This begins the study of geometry.
Quadratic equations, in the form of problems relating the areas and sides of rectangles, are solved by Babylonians.[5]
Pythagorean triples are first discussed in Babylon and Egypt, and appear on later manuscripts such as the Berlin Papyrus 6619.[6]
Multiplication tables in a base-60, rather than base-10 (decimal), system from Babylon.[7]

Primitive positional notation for numerals is seen in the Babylonian cuneiform numerals.[8] However, the lack of clarity around the notion of zero made their system highly ambiguous (e.g. 13200 would be written the same as 132).[9]
Similar triangles and side-ratios are studied in Egypt for the construction of pyramids, paving the way for the field of trigonometry.[10]

Ancient Egyptians study anatomy, as recorded in the Edwin Smith Papyrus. They identified the heart and its vessels, liver, spleen, kidneys, hypothalamus, uterus, and bladder, and correctly identified that blood vessels emanated from the heart (however, they also believed that tears, urine, and semen, but not saliva and sweat, originated in the heart, see Cardiocentric hypothesis).[11]
The Middle Kingdom of Egypt develops Egyptian fraction notation.
A numerical approximation for the square root of two, accurate to 6 decimal places, is recorded on YBC 7289, a Babylonian clay tablet believed to belong to a student.[12]
A Babylonian tablet uses 25⁄8 = 3.125 as an approximation for π, which has an error of 0.5%.[13][14][15]

The Rhind Mathematical Papyrus (a copy of an older Middle Kingdom text) contains the first documented instance of inscribing a polygon (in this case, an octagon) into a circle to estimate the value of π.[16][17]

Pythagoras's theorem is discovered by Baudhayana in the Hindu Shulba Sutras in Upanishadic India.[18] However, Indian mathematics, especially North Indian mathematics, generally did not have a tradition of communicating proofs, and it is not fully certain that Baudhayana or Apastamba knew of a proof.[citation needed]
Pell's equations are first studied by Baudhayana in India, the first diophantine equations known to be studied.[19]
Grammar is first studied in India (note that Sanskrit Vyākaraṇa predates Pāṇini).[20]
Thales of Miletus is credited with proving Thales's theorem.[21][22][23]
Maharshi Kanada gives the ideal of the smallest units of matter. According to him, matter consisted of indestructible minutes particles called paramanus, which are now called as atoms.[24]

The Sushruta Samhita shows an understanding of musculoskeletal structure (including joints, ligaments and muscles and their functions) (3.V).[25] It refers to the cardiovascular system as a closed circuit.[26] In (3.IX) it identifies the existence of nerves.[25]
Hippasus, a Pythagorean, discovers irrational numbers.[27][28]
Anaxagoras identifies moonlight as reflected sunlight.[29]
The Greeks start experimenting with straightedge-and-compass constructions.[30]
The earliest documented mention of a spherical Earth comes from the Greeks in the 5th century BC.[31]  It is known that the Indians modeled the Earth as spherical by 300 BC[32]
Empedocles describes thermal expansion.[33]
Antiphon discovers the method of exhaustion, foreshadowing the concept of a limit.
Greek philosophers study the properties of logical negation.
The first true formal system is constructed by Pāṇini in his Sanskrit grammar.[34][35]
Eudoxus of Cnidus states the Archimedean property.[36]
Thaetetus shows that square roots are either integer or irrational.
Thaetetus enumerates the Platonic solids, an early work in graph theory.
Menaechmus discovers conic sections.[37]
Menaechmus develops co-ordinate geometry.[38]
Mozi in China gives a description of the camera obscura phenomenon.
Around the time of Aristotle, a more empirically founded system of anatomy is established, based on animal dissection. In particular, Praxagoras makes the distinction between arteries and veins.

Aristotle differentiates between near-sighted and far-sightedness.[39] Graeco-Roman physician Galen would later use the term "myopia" for near-sightedness.Pāṇini's Aṣṭādhyāyī, an early Indian grammatical treatise that constructs a formal system for the purpose of describing Sanskrit grammar.
Pāṇini develops a full-fledged formal grammar (for Sanskrit).
Chanakya (also known as Kautilya) establishes the field of economics with the Arthashastra (literally "Science of wealth"), a prescriptive treatise on economics and statecraft for Mauryan India.[40]
In Mauryan India, The Jain mathematical text Surya Prajnapati draws a distinction between countable and uncountable infinities.[41]
Clay tablets from (possibly Hellenistic-era) Babylon describe the mean speed theorem.[42]

Greek mathematician Euclid in the Elements describes a primitive form of formal proof and axiomatic systems. However, modern mathematicians generally believe that his axioms were highly incomplete, and that his definitions were not really used in his proofs.
Finite geometric progressions are studied by Euclid in Ptolemaic Egypt.[43]
Euclid proves the infinitude of primes.[44]
Euclid proves the Fundamental Theorem of Arithmetic.
Euclid discovers the Euclidean algorithm.

Euclid publishes the Elements, a compendium on classical Euclidean geometry, including: elementary theorems on circles, definitions of the centers of a triangle, the tangent-secant theorem, the law of sines and the law of cosines.[45]
Euclid's Optics introduces the field of geometric optics, making basic considerations on the sizes of images.
Archimedes relates problems in geometric series to those in arithmetic series, foreshadowing the logarithm.[46]
Pingala in Mauryan India studies binary numbers, making him the first to study the radix (numerical base) in history.[47]
Pingala in Mauryan India describes the Fibonacci sequence.[48][49]

Pingala in Mauryan India discovers the binomial coefficients in a combinatorial context and the additive formula for generating them

{\displaystyle {\tbinom {n}{r}}={\tbinom {n-1}{r}}+{\tbinom {n-1}{r-1}}}

,[50][51] i.e. a prose description of Pascal's triangle, and derived formulae relating to the sums and alternating sums of binomial coefficients. It has been suggested that he may have also discovered the binomial theorem in this context.[52]
Eratosthenes discovers the Sieve of Eratosthenes.[53]
Archimedes derives a formula for the volume of a sphere in The Method of Mechanical Theorems.[54]
Archimedes calculates areas and volumes relating to conic sections, such as the area bounded between a parabola and a chord, and various volumes of revolution.[55]
Archimedes discovers the sum/difference identity for trigonometric functions in the form of the "Theorem of Broken Chords".[45]
Archimedes makes use of infinitesimals.[56]
Archimedes further develops the method of exhaustion into an early description of integration.[57][58]
Archimedes calculates tangents to non-trigonometric curves.[59]
Archimedes uses the method of exhaustion to construct a strict inequality bounding the value of π within an interval of 0.002.
Archimedes develops the field of statics, introducing notions such as the center of gravity, mechanical equilibrium, the study of levers, and hydrostatics.
Eratosthenes measures the circumference of the Earth.[60]
Aristarchus of Samos proposes a basic heliocentric model of the universe.[61]
Apollonius of Perga discovers Apollonius's theorem.
Apollonius of Perga assigns equations to curves.
Apollonius of Perga develops epicycles. While an incorrect model, it was a precursor to the development of Fourier series.
Hipparchos discovers the apsidal precession of the Moon's orbit.[62]
Hipparchos discovers Axial precession.
Hipparchos measures the sizes of and distances to the Moon and Sun.[63]
Magic squares appear in China. The theory of magic squares can be considered the first example of a vector space.
Zhang Cang in Northern China is credited with the development of Gaussian elimination.[64]

A precursor to long division, known as "galley division" is developed at some point. Its discovery is generally believed to have originated in India around the 4th century AD,[65] although Singaporean mathematician Lam Lay Yong claims that the method is found in the Chinese text The Nine Chapters on the Mathematical Art, from the 1st century AD.[66]
Heron's formula is discovered by Hero of Alexandria.[67]
Ptolemy formalises the epicycles of Apollonius.
Ptolemy publishes his Optics, discussing colour, reflection, and refraction of light, and including the first known table of refractive angles.
Galen studies the anatomy of pigs.[68]
Menelaus of Alexandria describes spherical triangles, a precursor to non-Euclidean geometry.[69]

The Almagest of Ptolemy contains evidence of the Hellenistic zero. Unlike the earlier Babylonian zero, the Hellenistic zero could be used alone, or at the end of a number. However, it was usually used in the fractional part of a numeral, and was not regarded as a true arithmetical number itself.

Ptolemy's Almagest contains practical formulae to calculate latitudes and day lengths.Diophantus' Arithmetica (pictured: a Latin translation from 1621) contained the first known use of symbolic mathematical notation. Despite the relative decline in the importance of the sciences during the Roman era, several Greek mathematicians continued to flourish in Alexandria.
Diophantus discusses linear diophantine equations.
Diophantus uses a primitive form of algebraic symbolism, which is quickly forgotten.[70]

Negative numbers are accepted as numeric by the late Han-era Chinese text The Nine Chapters on the Mathematical Art.[71] Later, Liu Hui of Cao Wei (during the Three Kingdoms period) writes down laws regarding the arithmetic of negative numbers.[72]
A square root finding algorithm with quartic convergence, known as the Bakhshali method (after the Bakhshali manuscript which records it), is discovered in India.[73]

The present Hindu–Arabic numeral system with place-value numerals develops in Gupta-era India, and is attested in the Bakhshali Manuscript of Gandhara[broken anchor].[74] The superiority of the system over existing place-value and sign-value systems arises from its treatment of zero as an ordinary numeral.

The modern fundamental trigonometric functions, sine and cosine, are described in the Siddhantas of India.[75] This formulation of trigonometry is an improvement over the earlier Greek functions, in that it lends itself more seamlessly to polar co-ordinates and the later complex interpretation of the trigonometric functions.
The decimal separator is developed in India,[76] as recorded in al-Uqlidisi's later commentary on Indian mathematics.[77]
The elliptical orbits of planets are discovered in India by at least the time of Aryabhata, and are used for the calculations of orbital periods and eclipse timings.[78]
Aryabhata's work shows the use of the modern fraction notation, known as bhinnarasi.[79]Example of the early Greek symbol for zero (lower right corner) from a 2nd-century papyrus
Aryabhata gives a new symbol for zero and uses it for the decimal system.
Aryabhata discovers the formula for the square-pyramidal numbers (the sums of consecutive square numbers).[80]
Aryabhata discovers the formula for the simplicial numbers (the sums of consecutive cube numbers).[80]
Aryabhata discovers Bezout's identity, a foundational result to the theory of principal ideal domains.[81]
Aryabhata develops Kuṭṭaka, an algorithm very similar to the Extended Euclidean algorithm.[81]
Aryabhata describes a numerical algorithm for finding cube roots.[82][83]
Aryabhata develops an algorithm to solve the Chinese remainder theorem.[84]

Historians speculate that Aryabhata may have used an underlying heliocentric model for his astronomical calculations, which would make it the first computational heliocentric model in history (as opposed to Aristarchus's model in form).[85][86][87] This claim is based on his description of the planetary period about the Sun (śīghrocca), but has been met with criticism.[88]

Aryabhata creates a particularly accurate eclipse chart. As an example of its accuracy, 18th century scientist Guillaume Le Gentil, during a visit to Pondicherry, India, found the Indian computations (based on Aryabhata's computational paradigm) of the duration of the lunar eclipse of 30 August 1765 to be short by 41 seconds, whereas his charts (by Tobias Mayer, 1752) were long by 68 seconds.[89]
Varahamira in the Gupta empire is the first to describe comets as astronomical phenomena, and as periodic in nature.[90]

John Philoponus in Byzantine Egypt describes the notion of inertia, and states that the motion of a falling object does not depend on its weight.[91] His radical rejection of Aristotlean orthodoxy lead him to be ignored in his time

Brahmagupta states the arithmetic rules for addition, subtraction, and multiplication with zero, as well as the multiplication of negative numbers, extending the basic rules for the latter found in the earlier The Nine Chapters on the Mathematical Art.[92]
Brahmagupta writes down Brahmagupta's identity, an important lemma in the theory of Pell's equation.
Brahmagupta produces an infinite (but not exhaustive) number of solutions to Pell's equation.
Brahmagupta provides an explicit solution to the quadratic equation.[93]
Brahmagupta discovers Brahmagupta's formula, a generalization of Heron's formula to cyclic quadrilaterals.
Brahmagupta discovers second-order interpolation, in the form of Brahmagupta's interpolation formula.
Brahmagupta invents a symbolic mathematical notation, which is then adopted by mathematicians through India and the Near East, and eventually Europe.
Bhāskara I produces the first approximation of a transcendental function with a rational function, in the sine approximation formula that bears his name.
Jain mathematician Mahāvīra writes down a factorisation for the difference of cubes.[94]

Algorisms (arithmetical algorithms on numbers written in place-value system) are described by al-Khwarizmi in his kitāb al-ḥisāb al-hindī (Book of Indian computation) and kitab al-jam' wa'l-tafriq al-ḥisāb al-hindī (Addition and subtraction in Indian arithmetic).[citation needed]
Mahāvīra discovers the first algorithm for writing fractions as Egyptian fractions,[95] which is in fact a slightly more general form of the Greedy algorithm for Egyptian fractions.
Jain mathematician Virasena describes the integer logarithm.[96]

Mahāvīra derives the expression for the binomial coefficient in terms of factorials,

{\displaystyle {\tbinom {n}{r}}={\tfrac {n!}{r!(n-r)!}}}

.[51]
Manjula in India discovers the derivative, deducing that the derivative of the sine function is the cosine.[97]
Kashmiri[98][99][100][101] astronomer Bhaṭṭotpala lists names and estimates periods of certain comets.[90]
Halayudha organizes the binomial coefficients into a triangle, i.e. Pascal's triangle.[51]
Ibn Sahl discovers Snell's law.[102][103]
Alhazen discovers the formula for the simplicial numbers defined as the sums of consecutive quartic powers.[citation needed]
Alhazen systematically studies optics and refraction, which would later be important in making the connection between geometric (ray) optics and wave theory.
Shen Kuo discovers atmospheric refraction and provides the correct explanation of rainbow phenomenon[citation needed]
Shen Kuo discovers the concepts of true north and magnetic declination.
Shen Kuo develops the field of geomorphology and natural climate change.
Al-Karaji uses mathematical induction.[104]
al-Zarqālī in Islamic Spain discovers the apsidal precession of the Sun.
Bhāskara II develops the Chakravala method, solving Pell's equation.[105]
Al-Tusi develops a numerical algorithm to solve cubic equations.
Jewish polymath Baruch ben Malka in Iraq formulates a qualitative form of Newton's second law for constant forces.[106][107]

Robert Grosseteste writes on optics, and the production of lenses, while asserting models should be developed from observations, and predictions of those models verified through observation, in a precursor to the scientific method.[108]

Roger Bacon publishes his Opus Majus, compiling translated Classical Greek, and Arabic works on mathematics, optics, and alchemy into a volume, and details his methods for evaluating the theories, particularly those of Ptolemy's 2nd century Optics, and his findings on the production of lenses, asserting  “theories supplied by reason should be verified by sensory data, aided by instruments, and corroborated by trustworthy witnesses", in a precursor to the peer reviewed scientific method.
Eyeglasses are invented in Northern Italy,[109] possibly Pisa, demonstrating knowledge of human biology and optics, to offer bespoke works that compensate for an individual human disability.
Scottish priest Duns Scotus writes about the mutual beneficence of trade.[110]
French priest Jean Buridan provides a basic explanation of the price system.
Madhava of Sangamagrama develops the Taylor series, and derives the Taylor series representation for the sine, cosine and arctangent functions, and uses it to produce the Leibniz series for π.[111]
Madhava of Sangamagrama discusses error terms in infinite series in the context of his infinite series for π.[112]
Madhava of Sangamagrama discovers continued fractions and uses them to solve transcendental equations.[113]
The Kerala school develops convergence tests for infinite series.[111]
Madhava of Sangamagrama solves transcendental equations by iteration.[113]
Madhava of Sangamagrama discovers the most precise estimate of π in the medieval world through his infinite series, a strict inequality with uncertainty 3e-13.
Parameshvara discovers a formula for the circumradius of a quadrilateral.[114]
Madhava of Sangamagrama found pi and that it was infinite.
Nilakantha Somayaji discovers an infinite series for π.[115]: 101–102 [116]

Nilakantha Somayaji develops a model similar to the Tychonic system. His model has been described as mathematically more efficient than the Tychonic system due to correctly considering the equation of the centre and latitudinal motion of Mercury and Venus.[97][117]
Gerolamo Cardano solves the general cubic equation (by reducing them to the case with zero quadratic term).
Lodovico Ferrari solves the general quartic equation (by reducing it to the case with zero quartic term).
François Viète discovers Vieta's formulas.

François Viète discovers Viète's formula for π.[118]1500: Scipione del Ferro solves the special cubic equation 




x

+
q


{\displaystyle x^{3}=px+q}

.[119][120]
Tycho Brahe proves that comets are astronomical (and not atmospheric) phenomena.
Nicolaus Copernicus develops the quantity theory of money and states the earliest known form of Gresham's law: ("Bad money drowns out good").[121]
Nicolaus Copernicus develops a heliocentric model, rejecting Aristotle's Earth-centric view, would be the first quantitative heliocentric model in history.
Vesalius: pioneering research into human anatomy.
Gerolamo Cardano discovers complex numbers.[122]
Niccolò Tartaglia introduces parenthesis.
Robert Recorde introduces the equal sign.[123][124]
Gerolamo Cardano is the first to produce a systematic treatment of probability.[125]
Rafael Bombelli provides rules for complex arithmetic.[126]
François Viète's New algebra shows the modern notational algebraic manipulation.
William Gilbert: Earth's magnetic field.
Earliest record of an optical telescope.
Johannes Kepler: first two laws of planetary motion.
Galileo Galilei: Sidereus Nuncius: telescopic observations.
John Napier: use of logarithms for calculation.[127]
Johannes Kepler: third law of planetary motion.
Appearance of the first compound microscopes in Europe.
Willebrord Snellius: the law of refraction also known as Snell's law.
William Harvey: blood circulation.
Galileo Galilei: laws of falling bodies.
Evangelista Torricelli invents the mercury barometer.
Robert Boyle: Boyle's law of ideal gases.
Philosophical Transactions of the Royal Society: first peer reviewed scientific journal published.
Robert Hooke: discovers the cell.
Francesco Redi: disproved idea of spontaneous generation.
Nicholas Steno: proposes that fossils are organic remains embedded in layers of sediment, basis of stratigraphy.
Jan Swammerdam: epigenesis in insects.
Sir Isaac Newton: discovers that white light is a mixture of distinct coloured rays (the spectrum).
Christiaan Huygens: first study of oscillating system and design of pendulum clocks
Leibniz, Newton: infinitesimal calculus.
Anton van Leeuwenhoek: observes microorganisms using a refined simple microscope.
Ole Rømer:  first measurement of the speed of light.
Sir Isaac Newton: classical mathematical description of the fundamental force of universal gravitation and the three physical laws of motion.
Carl Linnaeus described a new system for classifying plants in Systema Naturae.
Ewald Georg von Kleist first capacitor, the Leyden jar.
Buffon wrote Histoire naturelle.
Joseph Black: describes latent heat.
Benjamin Franklin: lightning is electrical.
Immanuel Kant: Gaseous Hypothesis in Universal Natural History and Theory of Heaven.
Mikhail Lomonosov: discovery of the atmosphere of Venus.
Thomas Bayes: publishes the first version of Bayes' theorem, paving the way for Bayesian probability.
Charles Messier: publishes catalogue of astronomical objects (Messier Objects) now known to include galaxies, star clusters, and nebulae.
Antoine Lavoisier (and Joseph Priestley): discovery of oxygen leading to end of Phlogiston theory.
William Herschel announces discovery of Uranus, expanding the known boundaries of the Solar System for the first time in modern history.
William Withering: publishes the first definitive account of the use of foxglove (digitalis) for treating dropsy.
Jacques Charles: Charles's law of ideal gases.
Antoine Lavoisier: law of conservation of mass, basis for chemistry, and the beginning of modern chemistry.
Georges Cuvier: Establishes extinction as a fact.
Edward Jenner: smallpox historical accounting.
Hanaoka Seishū: develops general anaesthesia.
Alessandro Volta: discovers electrochemical series and invents the battery.
Jean-Baptiste Lamarck: teleological evolution.
John Dalton: Atomic Theory in (chemistry).
Hans Christian Ørsted discovers that a current passed through a wire will deflect the needle of a compass, establishing the deep relationship between electricity and magnetism (electromagnetism).
Michael Faraday and James Stoddart discover alloying iron with chromium produces a stainless steel resistant to oxidising elements (rust).
Thomas Johann Seebeck is the first to observe a property of semiconductors.[citation needed]
Carnot: described the Carnot cycle, the idealized heat engine.
Joseph Aspdin develops Portland cement (concrete), by heating ground limestone, clay and gypsum, in a kiln.
Évariste Galois development of group theory.
Georg Ohm: Ohm's law (Electricity).
Amedeo Avogadro: Avogadro's law (Gas law).
Friedrich Wöhler synthesized urea, refuting vitalism.
Nikolai Lobachevsky created Non-Euclidean geometry.
Michael Faraday discovers electromagnetic induction.
Anselme Payen isolates first enzyme, diastase.
Charles Babbage proposes a design for the construction of a Turing complete, general purpose Computer, to be called the Analytical Engine.
Matthias Schleiden: all plants are made of cells.
Friedrich Bessel: first successful measure of stellar parallax (to star 61 Cygni).
Christian Doppler: Doppler effect.
James Prescott Joule: Law of Conservation of energy (First law of thermodynamics), also 1847 – Helmholtz, Conservation of energy.
Johann Gottfried Galle and Heinrich Louis d'Arrest: discovery of Neptune.
George Boole: publishes The Mathematical Analysis of Logic, defining Boolean algebra; refined in his 1854 The Laws of Thought.
Lord Kelvin: absolute zero.

Robert Forester Mushet develops a process for the decarbonisation, and re-carbonisation of iron, through the addition of a calculated quantity of spiegeleisen, to produce cheap, consistently high quality steel.
Rudolf Virchow: cells can only arise from pre-existing cells.
Charles Darwin and Alfred Wallace: Theory of evolution by natural selection.
Louis Pasteur: Germ theory.
John Tyndall:  Experiments in Radiant Energy that reinforced the Greenhouse effect.
James Clerk Maxwell: Theory of electromagnetism.
Gregor Mendel: Mendel's laws of inheritance, basis for genetics.
Rudolf Clausius: Definition of entropy.
Robert Forester Mushet discovers that alloying steel with tungsten produces a harder, more durable alloy.
Dmitri Mendeleev: Periodic table.
Lord Rayleigh: Diffuse sky radiation (Rayleigh scattering) explains why sky appears blue.
Johannes Diderik van der Waals: was one of the first to postulate an intermolecular force: the van der Waals force.
Frederick Guthrie discovers thermionic emission.
Willoughby Smith discovers photoconductivity.
William Crookes invented the Crookes tube and studied cathode rays.
Josiah Willard Gibbs founded chemical thermodynamics, the phase rule.
Ludwig Boltzmann: Statistical definition of entropy.

John Hopkinson develops three-phase electrical supplies, mathematically proves how multiple AC dynamos can be connected in parallel, improves permanent magnets, and dynamo efficiency, by the addition of tungsten, and describes how temperature effects magnetism (Hopkinson effect).
Pierre Curie and Jacques Curie: Piezoelectricity.
Jacobus Henricus van 't Hoff: discovered the laws of chemical dynamics and osmotic pressure in solutions (in his work "Études de dynamique chimique").
Albert A. Michelson and Edward W. Morley: Michelson–Morley experiment which showed a lack of evidence for the aether.
Friedrich Reinitzer discovers liquid crystals.
Dmitri Ivanovsky discovers viruses.
Wilhelm Conrad Röntgen discovers x-rays.
Henri Becquerel discovers radioactivity
Svante Arrhenius derives the basic principles of the greenhouse effect
J.J. Thomson discovers the electron in cathode rays
Martinus Beijerinck: concluded that a virus is infectious—replicating in the host—and thus not a mere toxin, and gave it the name "virus"
J.J. Thomson proposed the plum pudding model of an atom
Marie Curie discovered radium and polonium
J. J. O'Donnell discovers and documents the order-of-sequence for the sound of an approaching tornado
Max Planck: explains the emission spectrum of a black body
Albert Einstein: theory of special relativity, explanation of Brownian motion, and photoelectric effect
Walther Nernst: Third law of thermodynamics
Alfred Bertheim: Arsphenamine, the first modern chemotherapeutic agent
Fritz Haber: Haber Process for industrial production of ammonia
Robert Andrews Millikan: conducts the oil drop experiment and determines the charge on an electron
Williamina Fleming: the first white dwarf, 40 Eridani B
Ernest Rutherford: Atomic nucleus
Heike Kamerlingh Onnes: Superconductivity
Alfred Wegener: Continental drift
Max von Laue: x-ray diffraction
Vesto Slipher: galactic redshifts
Henrietta Swan Leavitt: Cepheid variable period-luminosity relation
Henry Moseley: defined atomic number
Niels Bohr: Model of the atom
Albert Einstein: theory of general relativity – also David Hilbert
Karl Schwarzschild: discovery of the Schwarzschild radius leading to the identification of black holes
Emmy Noether: Noether's theorem – conditions under which the conservation laws are valid
Arthur Eddington: Stellar nucleosynthesis
Frederick Banting, Charles Best, James Collip, John Macleod: isolation and production of insulin to control diabetes
Wolfgang Pauli: quantum Pauli exclusion principle
Edwin Hubble: the discovery that the Milky Way is just one of many galaxies
Erwin Schrödinger: Schrödinger equation (Quantum mechanics)
Cecilia Payne-Gaposchkin: Discovery of the composition of the Sun and that hydrogen is the most abundant element in the Universe
Werner Heisenberg: Uncertainty principle (Quantum mechanics)
Georges Lemaître: Theory of the Big Bang
Paul Dirac: Dirac equation (Quantum mechanics)
Edwin Hubble: Hubble's law of the expanding universe
Alexander Fleming: Penicillin, the first beta-lactam antibiotic
Lars Onsager's reciprocal relations, a potential fourth law of thermodynamics
Subrahmanyan Chandrasekhar discovers his eponymous limit of the maximum mass of a white dwarf star
Kurt Gödel: incompleteness theorems prove formal axiomatic systems are incomplete
James Chadwick: Discovery of the neutron
Karl Guthe Jansky discovers the first astronomical radio source, Sagittarius A
Ernest Walton and John Cockcroft: Nuclear fission by proton bombardment
Enrico Fermi: Nuclear fission by neutron irradiation
Clive McCay: Calorie restriction extends the maximum lifespan of another species
Otto Hahn, Lise Meitner and Fritz Strassmann: Nuclear fission of heavy nuclei
Isidor Rabi: Nuclear magnetic resonance
Oswald Avery proves that DNA is the genetic material of the chromosome
Howard Florey Mass production of penicillin
William Shockley, John Bardeen and Walter Brattain invent the first transistor
Claude Elwood Shannon: 'A mathematical theory of communication' a seminal paper in Information theory.
Richard Feynman, Julian Schwinger, Sin-Itiro Tomonaga and Freeman Dyson: Quantum electrodynamics
George Otto Gey propagates first cancer cell line, HeLa
Jonas Salk: developed and tested first polio vaccine
Stanley Miller: demonstrated that the building blocks of life could arise from primeval soup in the conditions present during early Earth (Miller-Urey experiment)
Frederick Sanger: demonstrated that proteins are sequences of amino acids
James Watson, Francis Crick, Maurice Wilkins and Rosalind Franklin: helical structure of DNA, basis for molecular biology
Chien Shiung Wu: demonstrated that parity, and thus charge conjugation and time-reversals, are violated for weak interactions
Riccardo Giacconi and his team discover the first cosmic x-ray source, Scorpius X-1
Lawrence Morley, Fred Vine, and Drummond Matthews:  Paleomagnetic stripes in ocean crust as evidence of plate tectonics (Vine–Matthews–Morley hypothesis).
Murray Gell-Mann and George Zweig: postulates quarks, leading to the standard model
Arno Penzias and Robert Woodrow Wilson: detection of CMBR providing experimental evidence for the Big Bang
Leonard Hayflick: normal cells divide only a certain number of times: the Hayflick limit
Jocelyn Bell Burnell and Antony Hewish discover first pulsar
Vela nuclear test detection satellites discover the first gamma-ray burst

James H. Ellis proposed the possibility of "non-secret encryption", more commonly termed public-key cryptography, a concept that would be implemented by his GCHQ colleague Clifford Cocks in 1973, in what would become known as the RSA algorithm, with key exchange added by a third colleague Malcolm J. Williamson, in 1975.
Place cells in the brain are discovered by John O'Keefe
Russell Alan Hulse and Joseph Hooton Taylor, Jr. discover indirect evidence for gravitational wave radiation in the Hulse–Taylor binary
Frederick Sanger sequences the first DNA genome of an organism using Sanger sequencing
Klaus von Klitzing discovered the quantum Hall effect
Donald C. Backer et al. discover the first millisecond pulsar
Kary Mullis invents the polymerase chain reaction, a key discovery in molecular biology
Karl Müller and Johannes Bednorz: Discovery of High-temperature superconductivity
Bart van Wees [nl] and colleagues at TU Delft and Philips Research discovered the quantized conductance in a two-dimensional electron gas.
Mary-Claire King discovers the link between heritable breast cancers and a gene found on chromosome 17q21.[128][129]
Aleksander Wolszczan and Dale Frail observe the first pulsar planets (this was the first confirmed discovery of planets outside the Solar System)
Andrew Wiles proves Fermat's Last Theorem
Michel Mayor and Didier Queloz definitively observe the first extrasolar planet around a main sequence star
Eric Cornell, Carl Wieman and Wolfgang Ketterle attained the first Bose-Einstein Condensate with atomic gases, so called fifth state of matter at an extremely low temperature.
Roslin Institute: Dolly the sheep was cloned.[130]
CDF and DØ experiments at Fermilab: Top quark.
Supernova Cosmology Project and the High-Z Supernova Search Team: discovery of the accelerated expansion of the Universe and dark energy
The Tau neutrino is discovered by the DONUT collaboration
The first draft of the Human Genome Project is published.[131]
Grigori Perelman presents proof of the Poincaré Conjecture.
The Human Genome Project sequences the human genome with a 92% accuracy.[132]
Ben Green and Terence Tao announce their proof on arithmetic progressions in prime numbers known as the Green–Tao Theorem.
Andre Geim and Konstantin Novoselov isolated graphene, a monolayer of carbon atoms, and studied its quantum electrical properties.
Grid cells in the brain are discovered by Edvard Moser and May-Britt Moser.
The first self-replicating, synthetic bacterial cells are constructed.[133]

The Neanderthal Genome Project presented preliminary genetic evidence that interbreeding likely occurred and that a small but significant portion of Neanderthal admixture is present in modern non-African populations.[134]
Higgs boson is discovered at CERN (confirmed to 99.999% certainty)
Photonic molecules are discovered at MIT
Exotic hadrons are discovered at the LHCb
Photonic metamaterials are discovered to make passive daytime radiative cooling possible by Raman et al.[135][136]
The LIGO team detects gravitational waves from a black hole merger

Gravitational wave signal GW170817 is observed by the LIGO/Virgo collaboration. This is the first instance of a gravitational wave event observed to have a simultaneous electromagnetic signal when space telescopes like Hubble observed lights coming from the event, thereby marking a significant breakthrough for multi-messenger astronomy.[137][138][139]
The first image of a black hole is captured, using eight different telescopes taking simultaneous pictures, timed with extremely precise atomic clocks. [1]
NASA and SOFIA (Stratospheric Observatory for Infrared Astronomy) discover about 12 US fl oz (350 ml) of surface water in one of the Moon's largest visible craters.[140]
The standard reference gene, GRCh38.p14, of the human genome, is fully sequenced and contains 3.1 billion base pairs.[141]
